'''Guest Star''': [[Cody Christian]] as Flint Forster '''Note''': Flint Forester is a reference to the Marvel Character [[Hawkeye (comics)]], an archer whose real name is Clint Barton. | LineColor= 50404D }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 29 | EpisodeNumber2= 3 | Title= Shadow Fly | DirectedBy= [[Clark Mathis]] | WrittenBy= Lanny Horn & Josh Silverstein | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|02|23}} | ProdCode=203 | Aux4= 1.4http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2013/02/26/saturdays-cable-ratings-nickelodeons-wendell-and-vinnie-tops-originals-in-viewers-448114/cable_20130223/{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/02/26/sunday-cable-ratings-walking-dead-wins-night-live-from-the-red-carpet-ax-men-bar-rescue-shameless-more/170856/comment-page-2/#comments|title=Sunday Cable Ratings: 'Walking Dead' Wins Night + 'Live From the Red Carpet', 'Ax Men', 'Bar Rescue', 'Shameless' & More |publisher= tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com |date= 25 February 2013 |accessdate=27 February 2013}} | ShortSummary= A photo of Owen in his ninja suit (beating a bad guy) goes viral. But an imposter steps up and pretends to be the Supah Ninjas, takes all the credit, and starts to sell T-shirts, hats, and jack-in-the-boxes. Meanwhile, Mike tries to find a new style to lose the nickname 'Necklace Guy', but in the end Mike figures out that his thing IS 'Necklace Guy'. '''Guest Star''': [[Bobb'e J. Thompson]] as Shadow Fly | LineColor= 50404D }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 30 | EpisodeNumber2=4 | Title= Grounded Ninja | DirectedBy= Clark Mathis | WrittenBy= [[Kristofor Brown]] | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|03|02}} | ProdCode=202 | Aux4= 1.3{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/03/05/sunday-cable-ratings-the-walking-dead-wins-night-the-bible-vikings-shameless-real-housewives-of-atlanta-pawn-stars-more/171909/comment-page-2/#comments|title=Sunday Cable Ratings: 'The Walking Dead' Wins Night, 'The Bible, 'Vikings', 'Shameless', 'Real Housewives of Atlanta', 'Pawn Stars' & More |publisher= tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com |date= 5 March 2013 |accessdate=5 March 2013}}http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2013/03/05/saturdays-cable-ratings-espn-tops-charts-with-college-basketball-doubleheader-365010/cable_20130302/ | ShortSummary= When Mike is grounded after his father catches him sneaking out, Mike has to find a way to help Owen and Amanda stop the Ishina and Kagema Fukanaga from finding the dojo. | LineColor= 50404D }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 31 | EpisodeNumber2= 5 | Title= Kid Q | DirectedBy= Dave Payne | WrittenBy= Mike Alber & Gabe Snyder | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|03|09}} | ProdCode= 204 | Aux4= 1.6{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2013/03/12/saturdays-cable-ratings-college-basketball-wendell-and-vinnie-top-viewers-628022/cable_20130309/|title=Saturday's Cable Ratings: College Basketball, "Wendell & Vinnie" Top Viewers |publisher= TheFutonCritic.com |date= March 12, 2013 |accessdate=March 13, 2013}} | ShortSummary= When Amanda and Mike pair up in the science fair, Owen gets stuck with Quinton as a science fair partner. Quiton does all the work and gets his project stolen from an evil scientist's assistant. | LineColor= 50404D }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 32 | EpisodeNumber2= 6 | Title= Cheer Fever | DirectedBy= Dave Payne | WrittenBy= Ray Lancon | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|03|16}} | ProdCode= 206 | Aux4= 1.4{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2013/03/19/saturdays-cable-ratings-college-basketball-ufc-prelims-top-demos-483110/cable_20130316/|title=Saturday's Cable Ratings: College Basketball, UFC Prelims Top Demos |publisher= TheFutonCritic.com|date= March 19, 2013 |accessdate=April 9, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/03/19/sunday-cable-ratings-the-walking-dead-wins-night-the-bible-vikings-the-client-list-shameless-army-wives-more/173794/comment-page-5/#comments|title=Sunday Cable Ratings: 'The Walking Dead' Wins Night, 'The Bible', 'Vikings', 'The Client List', 'Shameless', 'Army Wives' & More |publisher= Tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com|date= March 19, 2013 |accessdate=April 9, 2013}} | ShortSummary= During Spirit week, a rival cheerleader from Amanda's past named Kylie Coors is released from juvie and visits Benjamin Rush. Amanda doesn't trust her because she knows that she's up to something, so Owen and Mike go undercover as cheerleaders to find out what she's planning. '''Guest Star''': [[Ciara Bravo]] as Kylie | LineColor= 50404D }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 33 | EpisodeNumber2= 7 | Title= The Ishina Strike Back | DirectedBy= Alex Winter | WrittenBy= Mike Alber & Gabe Snyder | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|03|30}} | ProdCode= 207 | Aux4= N/A | ShortSummary= Mike throws a last minute birthday party for his dad Martin, but The Ishina strike back to try and steal the floating sword. In the end Grandpa is disabled and Yamato and the dojo are destroyed, and to repair it the ninjas bring in Quinton and expose their identities to him. | LineColor= 50404D }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 34 | EpisodeNumber2= 8 | Title= Enter the Dojo | DirectedBy= [[Lev L. Spiro]] | WrittenBy= Heather Flanders | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|04|06}} | ProdCode= 208 | Aux4= 1.3{{cite web|url=http://thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2013/04/09/saturdays-cable-ratings-marvin-marvin-wendell-and-vinnie-top-viewers-for-nickelodeon-543410/cable_20130406/|title=Saturday's Cable Ratings: "Marvin Marvin," "Wendell & Vinnie" Top Viewers for Nickelodeon|publisher= TheFutonCritic.com|date= April 9, 2013 |accessdate=April 21, 2013}} | ShortSummary= After the dojo is destroyed, the ninjas must expose their identities to Quentin and have him fix the dojo, but he overstates his welcome and lets Two-Ton Harley out of prison. | LineColor= 50404D }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 35 | EpisodeNumber2= 9 | Title= Finding Forster | DirectedBy= Lev L. Spiro | WrittenBy= Heather Flanders | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|04|13}} | ProdCode= 211 | Aux4= N/A | ShortSummary= Flint Forster returns and learns Amanda's real identity; Mike must rescue Flint and Amanda when they are taken hostage. In the end, Mike realizes he still has feelings for Amanda. '''Guest Star''': Cody Christian as Flint Forster '''Note''': This episode is a reference to ''[[Marvel's The Avengers]]'' as they have shawarma quietly in the end on the episode. | LineColor= 50404D |date=April 2013}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 36 | EpisodeNumber2= 10 | Title= Wallflower | DirectedBy= Clark Mathis | WrittenBy= Edward J. Bedrosian | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|04|20}} | ProdCode= 209 | Aux4= 1.5{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2013/04/23/saturdays-cable-ratings-nba-playoffs-tripleheader-puts-espn-on-top-135513/cable_20130420/ |title=Saturday's Cable Ratings: NBA Playoffs Tripleheader Puts ESPN on Top |publisher=TheFutonCritic.com |date= April 23, 2013|accessdate=April 23, 2013}} | ShortSummary= Owen pursues his crush on Paloma Peru, but gets captured by a girl who likes him; Mike and Amanda bond while filming an audition tape for a game show. '''Note''': Wallflower is a spoof of Poison Ivy from Batman. | LineColor= 50404D }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 37 | EpisodeNumber2= 11 | Title= M@yhem | DirectedBy= Dave Payne | WrittenBy= Josh Silverstein & Lanny Horn | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|04|27}} | ProdCode= 210 | Aux4= 1.2{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2013/04/23/saturdays-cable-ratings-nba-playoffs-tripleheader-puts-espn-on-top-135513/cable_20130420/ |title=Saturday's Cable Ratings: NBA Playoffs Tripleheader Puts ESPN on Top |publisher=TheFutonCritic.com |date= April 23, 2013|accessdate=April 23, 2013}} | ShortSummary= The Ninjas investigate a social media star who uses flash mobs to incite chaos; Paloma grows suspicious of the ninjas. | LineColor= 50404D }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 38 | EpisodeNumber2= 12 | Title= Spring Fling | DirectedBy= Dave Payne | WrittenBy= | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|5|3}} | ProdCode= 212 | Aux4= 1.3{{cite web|url=http://thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2013/04/30/saturdays-cable-ratings-nba-playoffs-marvin-marvin-top-charts-574213/cable_20130427/ |title=Saturday's Cable Ratings: NBA Playoffs, "Marvin Marvin" Top Charts |publisher=TheFutonCritic.com |date= April 30, 2013|accessdate=April 30, 2013}} | ShortSummary= Mike is left broken hearted when he misses his chance to ask Amanda to the dance. Instead she goes with Flint. To make matters worse, Flint reveals that Amanda is going to study abroad in Paris with him for the summer! In the end, Amanda decides to stay there with Mike and finds out that Mike still has feelings for her. '''Guest Star''': Cody Christian as Flint Forster | LineColor= 50404D }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber= 39 | EpisodeNumber2= 13 | Title= The Floating Sword[http://www.thefutoncritic.com/showatch/supah-ninjas/listings/ Production Code] | DirectedBy= Hiro Koda | WrittenBy= | OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2013|5|10}} | ProdCode= 213 | Aux4= 1.1 | ShortSummary= Mike's Cousin Connor returns as a spy and learns that the Kata is the key to finding the floating sword. He tries to retrieve it, but Mike defeats him and takes the sword. At the dojo, Quinton manages to fix Grandpa. In the last scene, Owen realizes that Amanda likes Mike. Mike goes to his locker and finds his grandpa's brother, who kidnaps Mike ending the series with Kagema flying off with Mike. | LineColor= 50404D }} |} == Awards and nominations == {| class="wikitable" |- ! revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = The Great Gabbo | image = greatgabbb.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Original theatrical poster | director = [[James Cruze]]
'''Uncredited:'''
[[Erich von Stroheim]] | producer = [[James Cruze]] | based on = {{Based on|"The Rival Dummy" (1928)|[[Ben Hecht]]}} | screenplay = [[Hugh Herbert]] | narrator = | starring = [[Erich von Stroheim]]
[[Betty Compson]] | music = [[Howard Jackson (composer)|Howard Jackson]] (musical arrangement)
'''Songs:'''
Lynn Cowan
Paul Titsworth
Donald McNamee
King Zany | cinematography = [[Ira H. Morgan]] | studio = James Cruze Productions | distributor = [[Sono Art-World Wide Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1929|09|12}} | runtime = 96 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Great Gabbo''''' (1929) is an American [[Pre-Code]] early [[sound film|sound]] musical drama film directed by [[James Cruze]], based on a story ("The Rival Dummy") by [[Ben Hecht]] and starring [[Erich von Stroheim]] and [[Betty Compson]].[http://www.afi.com/members/catalog/DetailView.aspx?s=&Movie=9486 The AFI Catalog of Feature Films: ''The Great Gabbo''] As originally released by [[Sono Art-World Wide Pictures]], the film featured sequences in [[Multicolor]]. The current prints, restored by the [[Library of Congress]] and released by [[Kino International (company)|Kino International]] on DVD, now exist only in black and white. Footage from the film was used on ''[[Fractured Flickers]]'' in the segment "Hymie und Me" (Episode 14), in which the dummy is presented as a real living comedian with von Stroheim as his straight man. ==Plot== The movie follows brilliant [[ventriloquist]] "The Great Gabbo" (Stroheim), who increasingly uses his dummy "Otto" as his only means of self-expression—an artist driven insane by his work. Gabbo's gimmick is his astonishing ability to make Otto talk—and even sing—while Gabbo himself smokes, drinks and eats. Gabbo's girlfriend and assistant Mary (Betty Compson) loves him, but is driven to leave him by his megalomania, superstitions, irritability, and inability to express any human emotion without using Otto as an intermediary. In Otto's voice Gabbo accepts the blame for Mary's leaving and recounts all the things she did for him, but as Gabbo he denies his feelings and tells the dummy to shut up. Two years later, Gabbo has become a nationally renowned ventriloquist. He is revered for his talent even as he is ridiculed for his eccentricity: he takes Otto with him everywhere he goes, even dining out with him, providing much entertainment to the restaurant patrons. Despite his success he continues to pine for Mary, who is now romantically involved with another singer/dancer, Frank (Donald Douglas). With both Mary and Frank performing in a show in which Gabbo is the headliner, he attempts to win her back. Mary is charmed by Gabbo's new romantic behavior, driving Frank to angry fits of jealousy. As his courtship meets with continued success, Gabbo increasingly expresses his emotions to Mary directly, without using Otto. One day Gabbo finds that in his absence, Mary has straightened up his dressing room the way she always used to. Convinced that she wants to come back to him, he confronts her with his feelings, admitting his loneliness without her and in the process revealing that he has grown past many of his old failings, such as his superstitions and obsession with his personal success. However, Mary tells him that she loves Frank, and has been married to him since before Gabbo came back into her life. She says that she missed Otto but not Gabbo, and in a last farewell she says "I love you" to Otto. In profound frustration at this, after Mary is gone Gabbo punches Otto in the face, but immediately apologizes and embraces the dummy, weeping. He then storms onto the stage during the finale and loudly rants at the performers. He is forced off the stage and fired from the show. Mary tries to confront Gabbo afterwards, but he only looks at her sadly and walks away. The film ends with workers taking down the letters of "The Great Gabbo" from the [[Marquee (sign)|marquee]] as Gabbo looks on. ==Cast== *[[Erich von Stroheim]] as The Great Gabbo *[[Betty Compson]] as Mary *[[Don Douglas|Donald Douglas]] as Frank *[[Marjorie Kane]] as Babe *George Grandee as Otto (voice) (uncredited) *[[John F. Hamilton]] as Neighbour (uncredited) *Harry Ross as Performer (uncredited) *Marbeth Wright as Dancer (uncredited) ==Production== Touted in advertising as an "all-dialog singing, dancing and dramatic spectacle", this early [[sound film]] oddly interleaves stark drama with gratuitous full-length, large-scale, on-stage musical [[Number (music)|production numbers]] such as "Every Now and Then", "I'm in Love with You", "The New Step", "The Web of Love", and the now-missing "The Ga Ga Bird", which was filmed in color. The "Web of Love" number, in which the performers wear stylized spider and fly costumes, is occasionally shown on [[Classic Arts Showcase]]. Footage from the dance sequences was re-used with different music in ''[[The Girl from Calgary]]'' (1932). The [[public domain]] version available on [[Internet Archive]] runs 68 minutes, while the original film ran 96 minutes, including the exit music. The [[opening credits]] mention "Color sequences by Multicolor", but those sequences are now either [[lost film|lost]] or have survived only in [[black-and-white]] form. Multicolor, based on the earlier [[Prizma]] color process, went out of business in 1932; its assets were bought by [[Cinecolor]]. The quality and clarity of the film sound is notable. A 94 minute public domain version is now available.{{cite web |title=The Great Gabbo |url=http://www.publicdomaintorrents.info/nshowmovie.html?movieid=215 |website=Public Domain Torrents |accessdate=1 July 2018}} ==Response== ''The Great Gabbo'' opened to lukewarm reviews. Stroheim received good notices, but the film did nothing to further his career.Lennig, Arthur. ''Stroheim'' ([[Lexington, Kentucky|Lexington]]: [[University Press of Kentucky]]) p 295. {{ISBN|0-8131-2138-8}} ''[[Photoplay]]'' called the film "a bitter disappointment... Cruze seems to have lost his sense of humor, and the lighting and scenario are terrible."Kreuger, Miles ed. ''The Movie Musical from Vitaphone to 42nd Street as Reported in a Great Fan Magazine'' (New York: [[Dover Publications]]) p 111. {{ISBN|0-486-23154-2}} The ''New York Times'' review commented unfavorably on the technical quality of the color sequences. Historian [[Arthur Lennig]] wrote that ''The Great Gabbo'' "betrays little inventiveness and shows few of its actors to advantage." He notes that, due to obvious budget constraints, several line-flubs by cast members made it into the final cut.Lennig, p 292. ==Soundtrack== *'''"Every Now and Then"''' :Sung by [[Marjorie Kane]] and [[Don Douglas|Donald Douglas]] *'''"I'm In Love With You"''' :Sung by [[Betty Compson]] and [[Don Douglas|Donald Douglas]] :Written by Lynn Cowan and Paul Titsworth *'''"The New Step"''' :Sung by [[Marjorie Kane]] and chorus :Written by Lynn Cowan and Paul Titsworth *'''"I'm Laughing"''' :Sung by Otto the dummy, with [[Erich von Stroheim]] :Written by King Zany and Donald McNamee *'''"Icky"''' (the lollipop song) :Sung by Otto the dummy, with [[Erich von Stroheim]] *'''"The Web Of Love"''' :Sung by [[Betty Compson]] and [[Don Douglas|Donald Douglas]] :Written by Lynn Cowan and Paul Titsworth *'''"The Ga Ga Bird"''' :(missing from known prints but major production number glimpsed among Gabbo's hallucinations) ==See also== *''[[Dead of Night]]'', a 1945 British film *''[[Knock on Wood (film)|Knock on Wood]]'', a 1954 film *"[[The Dummy]]" a 1962 episode of ''The Twilight Zone'' *"[[Caesar and Me]]", a 1964 episode of ''The Twilight Zone'' *''[[Devil Doll (film)|Devil Doll]]'', a 1964 film *''[[Magic (1978 film)|Magic]]'', a 1978 film *[[Ventriloquist (comics)|The Ventriloquist]], a nemesis in ''Batman'' comics, first appearing in 1988 *"[[Krusty Gets Kancelled]]", a 1993 episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]'' *[[List of early color feature films]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|The Great Gabbo}} *{{IMDb title|id=0019946|title=The Great Gabbo}} *{{allmovie|20668|Synopsis}} *[https://www.moma.org/collection/works/146154 Still] at moma.org *{{Internet Archive film|id=great_gabbo|name=The Great Gabbo}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2015}} {{James Cruze}} {{Ben Hecht}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Great Gabbo, The}} [[Category:1929 films]] [[Category:1920s musical films]] [[Category:1920s drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American musical drama films]] [[Category:German-language films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Ventriloquism]] [[Category:Films directed by James Cruze]] [[Category:Films made before the MPAA Production Code]]

revision.text:
{{about|the performance venue in New York City|other uses|Town Hall (disambiguation)}} {{coord|40.755986|-73.984712|display=title}} {{Infobox Theatre |name = The Town Hall |image = Town Hall 123 W43 near sun jeh.jpg |caption = |address = 123 West 43rd Street |city = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|NY]] |country = [[United States]] |designation = U.S. [[National Historic Landmark]] |architect = [[McKim, Mead & White]] |owner = Town Hall Foundation, Inc. |capacity = 1,495<ref>[http://www.the-townhall-nyc.org/seatingchart Seating Charts - the-townhall-nyc.org - Retrieved November 20, 2010] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128012108/http://www.the-townhall-nyc.org/seatingchart |date=November 28, 2010 }}</ref> |type = |opened = January 12, 1921 |yearsactive = 1921–current |rebuilt = |closed = |othernames = |production = |currentuse = |website = {{URL|http://the-townhall-nyc.org}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Town Hall | embed = yes | nrhp_type = nhl | designated_nrhp_type = March 2, 2012 | image = | caption = | location= 113--123 W. 43rd St., New York, NY | coordinates = {{coord|40|45|21|N|73|59|5|W|display=inline}} | locmapin = United States Manhattan#New York#USA | map_label =The Town Hall | built = 1919 | builder = van der Bent, Teunis J. | architecture = Late 19th And 20th Century Revivals, Other, Neo-Federal | added = April 23, 1980 | area = less than one acre | governing_body = Private | refnum = 80002724<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> }} }} '''The Town Hall''' is a performance space, located at 123 West 43rd Street, between [[Sixth Avenue (Manhattan)|Sixth Avenue]] and [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]], in [[midtown Manhattan|midtown]] [[Manhattan]] [[New York City]]. It opened on January 12, 1921, and seats approximately 1,500 people.
In the 1930s, the first public-affairs media programming originated here with the ''[[America's Town Meeting of the Air]]'' radio programs. In recognition of this the [[National Park Service]] placed the building on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2012,<ref name="NHL designation announcement">{{cite web|title=Weekly list of actions taken on properties 3/12/12 through 3/16/12|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/listings/20120323.htm|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|date=March 23, 2012|accessdate=March 23, 2012}}</ref> and designated it a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/29/new-york-town-hall-spotlight-celebration_n_2981191.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Curtis | last=Wong | title=Broadway, 'Smash' Stars Hit NYC's Town Hall For Historic Celebration | date=March 29, 2013}}</ref>
==History== The Town Hall was built by the [[League for Political Education]], whose fight for passage of the [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]] (women's suffrage) led them to commission the building of a meeting space where people of every rank and station could be educated on the important issues of the day. The space, which became The Town Hall, was designed by the renowned architectural firm of [[McKim, Mead & White]], to reflect the democratic principles of the League. To this end, box seats were not included in the theater's design, and every effort was made to ensure that there were no seats with an obstructed view. This design principle gave birth to The Town Hall's long-standing mantra: "Not a bad seat in the house."
It has not only become a meeting place for educational programs, gatherings of activists, and host for controversial speakers (such as the American advocate of [[birth control]], [[Margaret Sanger]], who was arrested and carried off The Town Hall stage on November 13, 1921, for attempting to speak to a mixed-sex audience about [[contraception]]), but as one of New York City's premiere performance spaces for music, dance, and other performing arts. While the lecture series and courses on political and non-political subjects sponsored by the League continued to be held there, The Town Hall quickly established a reputation as an arts center during the first fifteen years of its existence.
It has also had a long association with the promotion of poetry in the United States, which predates [[Edna St. Vincent Millay]]'s public poetry reading debut at the Hall in 1928. The Hall has retained a close association with poets and poetry that continues to this day.
=== ''America's Town Meeting of the Air'' === ''[[America's Town Meeting of the Air]]'' was a radio program produced at the Hall for over twenty years, from 1935 to 1956. ''Town Meeting'' was the brain-child of [[George V. Denny, Jr.]], then the associate director of the Hall. Envisioned as a means of expanding the audience — first nationally, then internationally — for the programs held at the Hall which promoted the free exchange of ideas, the format of ''Town Meeting'' was a conversation among four speakers on a predetermined question. The series was launched on the [[NBC Blue Network]] on [[Memorial Day]] 1935. Although it began broadcasting on a single station with approximately 500,000 listeners, within three years, ''Town Meeting'' was carried by 78 stations and boasted 2.5 million listeners. ''Town Meeting'' also toured the United States and twelve cities on three continents. It won numerous awards.
Recordings of ''America's Town Meeting of the Air'', from 1935 to 1952, are preserved at the United States' [[National Archives and Records Administration|National Archives]]' Donated Historical Materials collection, the catalog number of which is "DM.13".
The organizational records (archives) of Town Hall, Inc. and ''America's Town Meeting of the Air'', 1895–1955, are held by the Manuscripts and Archives Division of [[The New York Public Library]].
The Town Hall was owned by [[New York University]] for twenty years beginning in 1958.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TROUQlCmP8kC&pg=PA88 |title=Landmarks Preservation & the Property Tax |first=David |last=Listokin |page=88 |publisher=Transaction Publishers |year=2012 |accessdate=November 12, 2014}}</ref>
==Musical performances== The outstanding acoustic properties of Town Hall for musical performance — which some performers claim rival those of [[Carnegie Hall]] — were discovered during the first musical event held at the venue: a recital by Spanish violinist [[Juan Manén]] on February 12, 1921. Later in 1921, German composer [[Richard Strauss]] gave a series of concerts that cemented the Hall's reputation as an ideal space for musical performances. Aside from the acoustics, the sight lines and remarkable intimacy of the auditorium has made it a popular venue for both new and experienced artists, whatever the instrument, repertoire, or style of the performer. During the 1920s and 1930s, The Town Hall quickly gained a reputation amongst performers and audiences as "the place" for a performer to make a New York debut.
In 1928, The Hall began producing regular musical concert series, and over the next few seasons, ''The Town Hall Endowment Series'' featured artists including [[Sergei Rachmaninoff]], [[Ignacy Jan Paderewski]], [[Lily Pons]], [[Feodor Chaliapin]], [[Yehudi Menuhin]], and many more legends of the classical Western repertoire.
[[Marian Anderson]], considered one of the greatest [[contralto]]s ever born in the United States, made her New York debut at the Hall on December 30, 1935, after she had been denied an opportunity at an operatic career elsewhere due to [[discrimination]] against [[African-American]]s.
A notable world premiere in chamber music took place at the Town Hall on January 20, 1941, when the [[Kolisch Quartet]] gave the first performance of [[Béla Bartók]]'s [[String Quartet No. 6 (Bartók)|String Quartet No. 6]].<ref name="NY Times review">{{cite news|title=Bartok Quartet heard in premiere|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0F1FF9355F167B93C3AB178AD85F458485F9|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 21, 1941|accessdate=April 26, 2012}}</ref>
[[Eddie Condon]] led a series of nationally broadcast radio shows from New York's Town Hall during 1944–45.
Other important [[jazz]] concert appearances at The Town Hall include the June 22, 1945 concert — featuring [[Dizzy Gillespie]], on trumpet; [[Charlie Parker]], on alto saxophone; [[Don Byas]], on tenor saxophone; [[Al Haig]], on piano; [[Curley Russell]], on bass, and [[Max Roach]], on drums (with [[Sid Catlett]] substituting for Roach on a few titles) — which provided the public with its first mainstream exposure to the quickly evolving style of jazz that came to be popularly known as [[bebop]]. This concert illustrates how progressive The Town Hall's jazz programming has been since the venue's inception; prior to appearing in concert at the Hall, Gillespie and Parker had released only one 78-RPM release, and only Gillespie — due to his high-profile associations with [[Cab Calloway]], [[Earl Hines]], and [[Billy Eckstine]] — enjoyed mainstream name-recognition. (In June 2005, the [[Uptown Jazz]] label released a [[CD]] containing seven sonically restored performances transcribed from [[acetates]] made at the concert.) The Town Hall also hosted the 1947 concert that led to the re-invigoration of Louis Armstrong's career, and which led to the formation of [[Louis Armstrong#The All Stars|Louis Armstrong and His All Stars]], the small traditional jazz combo that he led for the last quarter-century of his life.
The Hall's tradition of jazz programming continues with the ''Not Just Jazz'' series of concerts, which also features poetry, film and dance. Past participants in the series include: [[Art Ensemble of Chicago|The Art Ensemble of Chicago]], the [[Lounge Lizards]], [[Cassandra Wilson]], [[Meredith Monk]], and [[Allen Ginsberg]].
On May 15, 1958, Town Hall hosted the 25th Year Retrospective Concert of the music of [[John Cage]]. This performance was recorded by Columbia Records producer [[George Avakian]], and the resulting 3-LP set was instrumental in making Cage's music known to many listeners.
Jazz composer and bandleader [[Charles Mingus]] also held two concerts here, resulting in his live albums from [[The Complete Town Hall Concert|October 1962]] and [[Town Hall Concert|April 1964]].
The Hall offers ''Morning Performances'', offered free of charge to public school students in grades 3 to 8, during the day. It also features programming in alliance with [[Theatreworks USA]] as part of its ''Arts in Education'' program.
When on tour, the radio show ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]'' is often broadcast live from Town Hall in its New York appearances.
In September 2009, singer [[Whitney Houston]] chose the Town Hall for her first interview in seven years, appearing on [[Oprah Winfrey]]'s season premiere. When asked by Winfrey why she chose the Town Hall, Whitney said it holds a special place in her heart because it's where she performed for the first time at the age of 14.
==See also== *{{category link|Albums recorded at the Town Hall}} *[[List of National Historic Landmarks in New York City]] *[[List of Peabody Award winners (1940-1949)]] *[[List of theaters in New York]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Manhattan from 14th to 59th Streets]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|The Town Hall (New York City)}} * {{Official website}}
{{National Register of Historic Places in New York}}

page.title: Timeline of cable television in the United Kingdom

revision.text:
This is a timeline of [[cable television]] in the United Kingdom.
The first part of the timeline covers the development of cable across the country, including details of the cable-exclusive channels which launched in the 1990s as part of cable television's attempt to compete with [[BSkyB]]'s [[satellite television]].
The merger of [[NTL Incorporated|NTL]] and [[Telewest]] effectively resulted in a single national network, covering just over half the country. The second part of the timeline covers [[Virgin Media]]. __FORCETOC__
==Pre-Virgin Media== * '''1928''' ** The foundations for cable television were laid in [[Swindon]] when a company called Radio Relay transmitted two audio channels on a wire that ran around the town to a relatively small number of homes.<ref>{{cite web|author=Writer Russ J Graham |url=http://www.transdiffusion.org/tmc/tvh/history/history.php |title=A short history of Rediffusion by Russ J Graham |publisher=Transdiffusion.org |date= |accessdate=2012-02-12}}</ref> * '''1950''' **A cable network was launched in [[Gloucester]], to provide better television reception than was possible at the time via a roof-top aerial.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aldricharchive.com/cable_systems.html |title=The Michael Aldrich Archive - Cable Systems |publisher=Aldricharchive.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-14}}</ref> Further such systems were built in other cities over the next three decades and by the late 1970s, 2.5 million British homes received their television service via cable.<ref>1982 Aldrich MJ co-author ''Cable Systems'' p18 HMSO London {{ISBN|0-11-630821-4}}</ref> * '''1961''' **A new cable network launches in [[Swindon]] to transmit television signals. As reception was poor, take-up was high and by the end of the decade around 15,000 homes were paying to receive their pictures via cable television. However, only those channels available in the area are allowed to be carried on the system. * '''1972''' ** The UK's Minister for Posts and Telecommunications authorises five experimental community cable television channels.<ref>{{cite book |title=Technology and In/equality: Questioning the Information Society |first1=Flis |last1=Henwood |first2=Nod |last2=Miller |first3=Peter |last3=Senker |first4=Sally |last4=Wyatt |publisher=Routledge |year=2002 |isbn=9780203134504 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iDW94RKbHcoC |pages=52–53}}</ref> * '''1973''' **The community cable television stations launch. They include [[Sheffield Cablevision]], [[Bristol Channel (TV station)|The Bristol Channel]] and [[Swindon Viewpoint]]. * '''1974''' **No events. * '''1975''' **March – After less than two years on air, [[Bristol Channel (TV station)|The Bristol Channel]] closes.<ref>{{cite newspaper |first=Peter |last=Fiddick |newspaper=The Guardian |title=The truth implicit in Rediffusion's pull-out |page=8 |date=24 March 1975}}</ref> * '''1976''' ** 2 January – [[Sheffield Cablevision]] closes when the funds run out.<ref name="Guardian">{{cite newspaper |newspaper=The Guardian |page=6 |title=Lack of funds closes local TV |date=2 January 1976}}</ref> **[[Swindon Viewpoint]]’s experimental phase ends when EMI decided to pull out of funding the service. However, the channel continues after it was sold to the public of Swindon for £1. * '''1977''' **No events. * '''1978''' **No events. * '''1979''' **No events. * '''1980''' ** April – Regular programming on [[Swindon Viewpoint]] ends when funding dries up.<ref>{{cite newspaper |newspaper=The Guardian |title=Mixed or matched |date=13 May 1980 |page=12}}</ref> but continues intermittently with programmes made by volunteers over the next decade. * '''1981''' **Radio Rental Cable Television launches the UK's first [[pay-per-view]] [[movie channel]], 'Cinematel' for cable viewers in [[Swindon]]. The channel later expands to [[Chatham, Kent|Chatham]] in Kent. **9 September – Following the [[Home Office]] granting several experimental licenses to broadcast subscription television. [[Rediffusion]] wins five of these licenses and one of the services it launches is a movie channel called [[Starview]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://archive.org/details/WirelessWorldNovember1981|title=Subscription tv by cable|publisher=Wireless World|date=November 1981}}</ref> * '''1982''' **Proposals to liberalise cable television in the UK are drawn up. Previously, apart from the 1981 experiments, the cable networks were only allowed to relay the over-the-air channels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aldricharchive.com/cable_story.html |title=The Michael Aldrich Archive - The Cable Story |publisher=Aldricharchive.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-14}}</ref> This led to the Cable and Broadcasting Act 1984 which allowed cable companies to offer as many channels as they liked and also allowed cable companies to offer a telephone service in competition with [[British Telecom]]. * '''1983''' **Ahead of the enacting of the forthcoming liberalisation, the Government licence eleven interim franchises for broadband systems. Each covers an individual town or city of around 100,000 homes. **16 October – [[Sky One|Satellite Television Ltd]] launches in the UK on [[Swindon Cable]] and is renamed Sky Channel. The channel initially broadcasts for five hours each night and as more operators start to carry the channel, its broadcast hours slowly expand.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KNAoWTAlSas SKY Television launch in Swindon - News reports]</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8eUTDMRidDU Sky Channel Swindon launch]</ref> * '''1984''' **[[Thorn EMI]], which operates [[Swindon Cable]], launches three channels – movie channel [[Premiere (TV channel)|Premiere]], [[Music Box (TV channel)|Music Box]] and [[The Children's Channel]]. Delivered by satellite, they are created with the planned roll-out of cable across the UK in mind. **1 December – The [[Cable Authority]] comes into existence and on 1 January 1985 takes on the functions granted to it by the Cable and Broadcasting Act 1984, paving the way for fully commercial cable franchises to be awarded on a city-by-city basis. * '''1985''' **[[Performance Channel|The Performance Channel]] launches. It broadcasts arts programming each night from 7pm until the early hours. It remained as a cable-exclusive channel until 2003 and ended broadcasting in July 2008.<ref>[http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/broadcasting/a103607/performance-channel-to-end-after-23-years.html Broadcasting - News - Performance Channel to end after 23 years - Digital Spy<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ** September – [[Home Video Channel|HVC]] launches. Showing movies, the channel is created by Ealing Cable and is subsequently rolled out to other cable operators by sending them tapes of the programmes and a copy of the programme schedule so that HVC could be played out locally.<ref>From Tony Currie Controller of Programmes at the Cable Authority from 1987 – 1991</ref> ** 31 December – United Artists Programming launches [[Bravo (UK TV channel)|Bravo]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Clover |first=Julian |url=http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2010/09/16/sky-shuts-bravo-after-25-years/ |title=Sky shuts Bravo after 25 years. |publisher=Broadband TV News |date=16 September 2010 |accessdate=25 July 2013}}</ref> It shows mainly [[Black-and-white|black & white]] B-movies from the 1950s and 1960s. The channel remains a cable-exclusive service until it launches on satellite in July 1993. * '''1986''' ** No events. * '''1987''' ** No events. * '''1988''' ** United Cable of Denver purchases Croydon Cable and subsequently merges with United Artists Cable International. * '''1989''' ** 5 February – Satellite television service [[Sky Television plc|Sky Television]] launches. The new channels – [[Sky News]], [[Sky Movies]] and [[Eurosport]] – are carried on cable. **31 July – Hampered by the very slow roll-out of cable television and increased competition from the launch of [[Sky Movies]], [[Premiere (TV channel)|Premiere]] closes. * '''1990''' ** 25 March – [[British Satellite Broadcasting]] (BSB) launches its five-channel service. As well as launching on satellite, the channels are carried by cable providers. However, the company merged in November with Sky TV and a month later two of the five BSB channels were closed down. **In its final annual report, published at its demise, the Cable Authority stated that by the end of 1990, even though almost 15 million homes had been included in franchised areas, only 828,000 of these had been passed by broadband cable and only 149,000 were subscribing.<ref>Cable Authority, Final Report and Accounts 1990</ref> * '''1991''' **1 January – The [[Independent Television Commission]] takes over the licensing and regulation of cable from The Cable Authority. **8 June – United Artists merges with its largest shareholder [[Tele-Communications Inc.]] (TCI).<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/08/business/company-news-tele-communications-in-united-artists-deal.html | title=United Artists deal | work=The New York Times | date=8 June 1991 }}</ref> * '''1992''' **The major cable companies join together to form 'Cable Programme Partners One (CPP1)', to try to provide alternative content to the satellite-dominated multi-channel environment of the time. **13 January – United Artists Cable launches [[BBC Parliament|The Parliamentary Channel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199798/cmselect/cmbroad/984/8071504.htm|title=Broadcasting Select Committee Minutes of Evidence, 1997}}</ref> **April – On-demand music video channel [[The Box (UK and Ireland TV channel)|The Box]] launches. Initially launched in four cable areas, it slowly rolls out on a regional basis across the entire cable network before getting its first berth on satellite in 1998. **May – [[Wire TV]] launches. Branding itself as 'The Cable Channel', this is the flagship channel of CPP1. The channel broadcasts a mix of entertainment, lifestyle and sport from 1pm until 11pm and includes two hours each day of regional programming. **October – Country music channel [[CMT Europe]] launches on cable. The following year it also starts part-time broadcasts on [[Astra 19.2°E|Astra]] and it doesn't get a full-time berth on satellite until later in the 1990s. **Following the merger of TCI and United Artists, they launch a joint venture called [[Telewest Communications]]. * '''1993''' **[[Barclay Knapp]] and George Blumenthal, the founders of the cellular network company Cellular Communications, Inc. (sold to [[AirTouch|Airtouch]] in 1996), establish ''International CableTel''. * '''1994''' **January – TCI acquires a 60.4% stake in Flextech<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/03/business/merger-plans-for-flextech.html |title=Merger Plans For Flextech |publisher=The New York Times |date=3 January 1994 |accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> and Flextech acquires 100% of [[Bravo (UK TV channel)|Bravo]], 25% of [[UK Gold]], 31% of [[UK Living]], and 25% of [[The Children's Channel]].<ref name="telecompaper.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.telecompaper.com/news/flextech-set-to-acquire-tci-programming |title=Flextech Set To Acquire TCI Programming |publisher=Telecompaper |date=21 December 1993 |accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> ** February – [[Travel Channel International|Travel]] launches exclusively on cable, broadcasting daily between midday and midnight. **2 March – [[Wire TV]]’s backers outbid [[BSkyB]] to the rights for the [[1996 Cricket World Cup]] as part of a plan to set up a sports channel to take on [[Sky Sports]].<ref>[http://www.variety.com/article/VR118799.html?categoryid=19&cs=1 A cricket coup for UK cable] Variety, 2 March 1994</ref> Wire TV's evening programming is by now devoted to sport under the name ''Sportswire'' with the daytime entertainment programming called ''LiveWire''.<ref>[http://www.allbusiness.com/company-activities-management/company-structures-ownership/7529251-1.html Sporting push for UK cable-only channel] Screen Digest, 1 March 1994</ref> **November – [[Associated Newspapers]] launches Channel One, a network of city news channels. The first to launch is in London. * '''1995''' **[[Bell Cablemedia]] is formed when a number of cable companies, including [[Jones Intercable|Jones Cable UK]], merge. **16 January – [[Trinity Mirror|Mirror Group plc]] launches Mirror Television by purchasing [[Wire TV]]. It plans to launch ''Sportswire'' as a full-time channel and replace Wire TV with a new channel called [[L!VE TV]]. **May – Ahead of the planned launch of ''Sportswire'' as a full-time channel, [[Wire TV]] closes.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_19950216/ai_n13966309 Mirror Group buys cable TV channel] The Independent, 16 February 1995</ref> **1 June – [[Carlton Select|SelecTV]] launches. It is a general entertainment channel which broadcasts each night from 5pm until midnight. **June – TCI (owners of Telewest) and [[NYNEX]], two of the main players of CPP1, do a deal with BSkyB which includes a clause that the cable operators do not launch any rival channels to those already operated by Sky. This marks the end of CPP1 and causes the collapse of sports channel ''Sportswire,'' days before its launch. **12 June – [[L!VE TV]] launches as Mirror Television's sole television channel. **June – Telewest merges with SBC Communications, adding franchises in the Midlands and North West serving 1.3 million homes. **1 October – [[Syfy (UK and Ireland)|The Sci Fi Channel]] launches in the UK but its full-time hours (8am to 4am) are only broadcast on cable due to a lack of space on satellite. It broadcasts on satellite for only three hours each evening, and viewers have to wait until the launch of [[Sky Digital (UK & Ireland)|Sky Digital]] to see the channel's full-time hours. * '''1996''' ** CableTel acquires National Transcommunications Limited (NTL), the [[privatization|privatised]] UK [[Independent Broadcasting Authority]] transmission network. ** 1 September – ***[[Carlton Food Network]] launches. It broadcasts on weekday afternoons and shares space with [[Carlton Select|SelecTV]]. ***[[The Weather Network]] and [[The Weather Channel]] launch on various cable networks. They use the regional nature of cable to provide regional weather forecasts. However both channels are gone within two years due to low viewership. ***A number of cable companies drop [[CMT Europe]]. This dents its reach and the channel closes 18 months later. * '''1997''' **14 February – SelecTV is rebranded [[Carlton Select]] following [[Carlton Television]]’s purchase of Pearson Television. **[[Bell Cablemedia]], [[NYNEX]] and [[Videotron]] merge to become [[Cable & Wireless Communications]].<ref name="CWC-H-18">[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/mercurys-pounds-5bn-merger-with-cable-firms-heralds-huge-telecoms-indu-stry-shakeup-1359751.html Mercury's pounds 5bn merger with cable firms heralds huge telecoms indu stry shake-up] ''The Independent'' {London}, Chris Godsmark and Mathew Horsman, 23 October 1996</ref> **9 November – As part of its foray into digital television, the BBC launches [[BBC News 24]]. However, the channel launches almost a year prior to the launch of digital television in the UK and therefore is only available 24 hours a day on cable, with other viewers only able to watch the channel overnight on [[BBC One]]. **[[FilmFlex|Front Row]] is created to provide a near on-demand pay-per-view movies service for cable television. However, [[Cable and Wireless]] chooses not to carry the service, instead opting for [[Sky Box Office]]. * '''1998''' ** March – [[Telewest]] and General Cable merge.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_/ai_n14160469?ref=HadiZayifla.Com | title=Telewest in £649m merger | accessdate=1 January 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> **[[Telewest]] also acquires the outstanding interest in Birmingham Cable, adding a further 1.7 million franchise homes in Yorkshire, west London and Birmingham. **19 May – CableTel adopts NTL as its new name. **23 September – The BBC purchases The Parliamentary Channel and relaunches it as [[BBC Parliament]]. **25 September – Channel One closes at 6pm.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v3512ujFzCY The last hour of Channel One London]</ref> ** 1 October – [[Sky UK|Sky Digital]] launches, becoming the UK's first digital television service. Consequently, a number of channels which had only been available full-time on cable are now able to broadcast their full schedule on satellite. ** 15 November – Rival digital television service [[ITV Digital|OnDigital]] launches. Two of its channels are channels which had been exclusive to cable – [[Carlton Food Network]] and [[Carlton Select]]. * '''1999''' **1 May – After 14 years on air, [[Home Video Channel|HVC]] closes. **August – [[Telewest]] purchases the remaining 50% stake in [[Cable London]] from NTL, adding 0.4 million franchise homes in [[North London]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/the_company_file/430565.stm | title=Telewest buys Cable London |work=BBC News | accessdate=1 January 2009 | date=26 August 1999}}</ref> **5 November – [[LIVE TV]] closes. **By the end of 1999, [[Cable & Wireless Communications]] launches its digital television service. **The regional [[The Box (UK and Ireland TV channel)|The Box]] stations close in favour of a single national channel. * '''2000''' ** 19 April – [[Telewest]] and [[Flextech]] merge.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/telewest-merger-with-flextech-would-challenge-murdoch-grip-740955.html | title=Telewest merger with Flextech would challenge Murdoch grip | work=The Independent | location=London | first=Bill | last=McIntosh | date=7 December 1999 | accessdate=1 January 2009}}</ref> ** 1 August – The [[ITN News Channel]] launches. It is a joint venture between ITN and [[NTL Incorporated|NTL]]. **November – Telewest acquires [[Eurobell]], taking the total number of homes passed to 4.9 million. **[[NTL Incorporated|NTL]] acquires the domestic cable business of Cable & Wireless Communications. **[[Telewest]] and [[NTL Incorporated|NTL]] launch their digital television services. * '''2001''' ** January – Cable television comes to the [[Isle of Wight]] when operator [[WightFibre|Isle of Wight Cable and Telephone Company]] launches. The island remains the only part of the UK's cable network not to be owned by Virgin Media. ** 1 February – [[NTL Incorporated|NTL]] launches movie channel [[The Studio (TV channel)|The Studio]] in conjunction with [[Vivendi Universal]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a1207/universal-and-ntl-to-launch-film-channel.html|title=Universal and ntl to launch film channel|last=Wilkes|first=Neil|date=29 September 2000|accessdate=9 June 2012|publisher=Digital Spy}}</ref> * '''2002''' **May – Less than a year after being founded and less than six months after launching,<ref>{{cite web|last=Satchell |first=Luke |url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/omne-communications-set-to-launch-local-tv-networks/1186685.article |title=OMNE Communications set to launch local TV networks |publisher=Broadcast |date=4 December 2001 |accessdate=5 February 2014}}</ref> [[Smallworld Cable|Omne Communications]] enters [[Administration (law)|administration]]. **June – [[Carlton Television]] and [[Granada Television]] purchase ITN's 65% stake in the ITN News Channel. **30 September – The ITN News Channel is relaunched as the [[ITV News Channel]]. **Following the purchase of Isle of Wight Cable and Telephone Company by [[CLS Holdings]], the service is renamed [[WightCable]]. * '''2003''' **1 January – [[The Studio (TV channel)|The Studio]] closes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1114937/000112528203005557/b327400_ex99-3.htm |title=Presentation to the Special Committee of the Board of Directors of NTL Europe, Inc. |publisher=U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission |date=30 September 2003 |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref> **1 February – [[CLS Holdings]], owners of [[WightFibre|WightCable]], acquires a 76% stake in Omne Communications for £4.1 million, saving it from closure<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith |first=Mark |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/buy-out-deal-secures-future-of-omne-communications-1.127481 |title=Buy-out deal secures future of Omne Communications |publisher=The Herald |date=1 February 2003 |accessdate=5 February 2014}}</ref> and later in 2003, Omne is rebranded WightCable North. **29 December – [[Ofcom]] replaces the [[Independent Television Commission]] as the UK's television regulator.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/3354093.stm|title='Super-regulator' Ofcom launches|publisher=BBC News|date=29 December 2003}}</ref> * '''2004''' ** April – The newly created [[ITV plc]] purchases NTL's 35% stake in the [[ITV News Channel]]. *'''2005''' ** January – [[NTL Incorporated|NTL]] rolls out its first video-on-demand services. Telewest also launches its first on demand services in 2005. ** [[CLS Holdings]] sells the assets of Wightcable to private investors in 2005, who formed WightCable (2005) Ltd and in 2012 WightCable was rebranded as WightFibre. ** 1 December – [[Telewest]] launches its first [[personal video recorder]] ''TV Drive''. * '''2006''' **At the start of 2006, Telewest becomes the first company in the UK to launch a [[High-definition television|high-definition]] service.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/multi-platform/news/telewest-beats-sky-to-hd-launch/1032894.article | title=Telewest beats Sky to HD launch | publisher=Broadcast Now }}</ref> It provides between 10 and 30 hours of on-demand content in HD, and that summer it provides HD access to some [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] matches to customers who have the ''TV Drive'' box. **January – [[CLS Holdings]] sells [[WightFibre|WightCable North]], at a loss of £2.1 million, to Netfonics<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clsholdings.com/clsholdings/uploads/press/CLSHoldingsplc-2006prelimannouncement.pdf |title=CLS Holdings Plc Preliminary Financial Results 2006 |publisher=CLS Holdings |accessdate=5 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://point-topic.com/content/operatorSource/profiles2/wightcable-north.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011174831/http://point-topic.com/content/operatorSource/profiles2/wightcable-north.htm |title=Wight Cable North – Operator Profile |publisher=Point Topic |archivedate=11 October 2007 |accessdate=5 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Just over a year later WightCable North is rebranded as Smallworld Media, then to Smallworld Cable (2009) and to Smallworld Fibre in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ferguson |first=Andrew |url=http://www.thinkbroadband.com/news/3024-wight-cable-north-re-branding-to-smallworld.html |title=Wight Cable North re-branding to Smallworld |publisher=ThinkBroadband |date=15 March 2007 |accessdate=5 February 2014}}</ref> **March – [[NTL Incorporated|NTL]] and [[Telewest]] merge.
==Virgin Media== * '''2006''' ** 8 November – [[Virgin Media]] comes into being when NTL Telewest does a deal to licence the Virgin name.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/nov/08/citynews.digitalmedia NTL rebrands as Virgin Media]</ref> * '''2007''' **February – The [[Virgin Media]] brand is launched. ** 20 February – Virgin launches its new on-demand channel [[Virgin Central]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/feb/20/itv.television Virgin Central launches without ITV]</ref> ** 1 March – The [[Sky UK|Sky]] Basics channels stop broadcasting on [[Virgin Media]] when the two companies cannot agree a new carriage deal.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/mar/01/bskyb.broadcasting2 Virgin customers wake up to no Sky channels]</ref> ** 1 June – In a bid to increase take-up if its [[V+]] [[personal video recorder]], XL TV{{Clarify|reason=Who/what is XL TV?|date=August 2018}} customers are given the [[V+]] box free as part of their package.<ref name="V+£75">{{Cite web|url=http://pressoffice.virginmedia.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=205406&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1081290&highlight=|title=Virgin Media sleighs price of V+|publisher=''Virgin Media''|date=2007-11-27}}</ref><ref name="V+bundles">{{Cite web|url=http://allyours.virginmedia.com/html/specialoffers/vplus.html|title=V+ bundles|publisher=''Virgin Media''|accessdate=2007-11-27}}</ref> **26 July – Virgin Media and [[Setanta Sports]] sign a deal to allow VM's XL customers free access to Setanta Sports.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/jul/20/broadcasting.digitaltvradio Setanta signs Virgin Media sports deal]</ref> **1 October – [[Channel One (UK and Ireland)|Virgin1]] is launched amid the continued stand-off between Virgin Media and [[BSkyb|BSkyB]]. The channel is intended as a replacement for [[Sky One]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/jun/11/bskyb.broadcasting Virgin to launch Sky One rival]</ref> **29 November – [[Setanta Sports News]] launches. For Virgin Media customers this is a direct replacement for [[Sky Sports News]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/jul/24/broadcasting.virginrichardbranson Setanta plans sports news channel]</ref> * '''2008''' ** 30 April – The [[BBC iPlayer]] becomes available for the first time on Virgin Media.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/apr/30/technology.virginmedia BBC IPlayer launched on Virgin Media]</ref> ** 13 November – The Sky Basics channels return to [[Virgin Media]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/nov/04/bskyb-virginmedia Sky and Virgin Media resolve distribution row]</ref> * '''2009''' **23 June – [[Setanta Sports]] stops broadcasting.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jun/23/setanta-goes-into-administration Setanta goes off air with loss of more than 200 jobs]</ref> ** 3 August – ***ESPN launches its UK television sports channel and is made available to all of Virgin's XL TV customers.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jul/29/espn-premier-league-football ESPN football to be free for first month on cable]</ref> ***[[ESPN Classic (UK)|ESPN Classic]] launches on [[Virgin Media]]. ** 24 November – Virgin Media enters into a strategic partnership with [[TiVo]].<ref name="Virgin Media Selects Tivo">{{cite web|url=http://pressoffice.virginmedia.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=205406&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1359213&highlight=|title=Virgin Media Selects Tivo For Next Generation Tv Platform|publisher=Virgin Media|date=24 November 2009}}</ref> Under the mutually exclusive agreement, TiVo will develop a converged television and broadband interactive interface to power Virgin Media's next generation, high definition [[Set-top box|set top boxes]]. TiVo becomes the exclusive provider of middleware and user interface software for Virgin Media's next generation set top boxes. Virgin Media will be the exclusive distributor of TiVo services and technology in the United Kingdom. *'''2010''' **4 June – British Sky Broadcasting and Virgin Media announce that they have reached an agreement for the acquisition by Sky of [[Virgin Media Television (2007–10)|Virgin Media Television]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://about.virginmedia.com/press-release/417/bskyb-and-virgin-media-reach-agreements-on-sale-of-vmtv-and-channel-distribution |title=BSkyB and Virgin Media reach agreements on sale of VMtv and channel distribution |publisher=Virgin Media |date=4 June 2010 |accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://corporate.sky.com/page.aspx?pointerid=6123cbfe61d648e38fb10a1e7a2024e5 |title=BSkyB and Virgin Media Reach Agreements on Sale of VMtv and Channel Distribution |publisher=BSkyB |date=4 June 2010 |accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> The take-over is completed on 13 July.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jul/13/bskyb-virginmedia BSkyB completes Virgin Media Television take-over]</ref> **20 July – [[Film4|Film4 HD]] launches exclusively on [[Virgin Media]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://about.virginmedia.com/press-release/387/film4-hd-to-launch-exclusively-on-virgin-media |title=Film4 HD to launch exclusively on Virgin Media |publisher=Virgin Media |date=2010-03-08 |accessdate=2013-08-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.film4.com/film4-hd |title=Film4 HD |publisher=Film4 |accessdate=2010-07-07}}</ref> and remains exclusive to the platform until it launches on Sky in 2013. **3 September – Virgin's general entertainment channel Virgin 1 is rebranded as [[Channel One (UK TV channel)|Channel One]] because the Virgin name was not licensed to Sky. **December – Virgin Media releases its first [[TiVo]] co-branded product.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a290840/virgin-medias-tivo-platform-to-go-live.html|title=Virgin Media's TiVo platform to go live|publisher=Digital Spy|date=1 December 2010}}</ref> On 17 March 2011, Virgin Media enabled access to a third tuner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a309547/virgin-media-unlocks-third-tivo-tuner.html|title=Virgin Media unlocks third TiVo tuner|publisher=Digital Spy|date=17 March 2011}}</ref> *'''2011''' ** 1 February – [[Sky Atlantic]] launches. However the channel does not launch on Virgin Media and to this day it is still not available on the cable platform. **early 2011 – [[video on demand]] content from [[ESPN Classic (UK)|ESPN Classic]] starts to appear on the Virgin Media platform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/broadcasting/news/a303235/espn-classic-vod-coming-to-virgin-media.html|title=ESPN Classic VOD coming to Virgin Media|publisher=Digital Spy|date=2011-02-11}}</ref> **May – Virgin Media carries [[Eurosport]]'s [[3D television|3D]] coverage of the [[French Open]] tennis tournament. **July – [[BSkyB]]’s on demand service [[Sky Anytime]] becomes available on Virgin Media.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.virginmedia.com/movies/features/sky-anytime-on-virgin-media.php|title=Sky Anytime on Virgin Media TV|publisher=Virgin Media|date=11 October 2011}}</ref> ** 15 August – [[Virgin Media]] agrees to sell its 50% stake in [[UKTV]] to [[Scripps Networks]] for £339m.<ref name="Scripps">{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/04a841ee-c729-11e0-a9ef-00144feabdc0|title=Virgin Media sells £239m stake in UKTV|work=Financial Times|date=15 August 2011}}</ref> **19 December – Virgin Media signs a deal with [[BBC Sport]] allowing the cable company to provide extra coverage of sports events, including live video streams of the [[2012 Olympic Games]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/dec/19/virgin-media-sports-deal VM signs BBC sports coverage deal]</ref> *'''2012''' **January – Virgin Media shuts down its analogue service in [[Westminster]]. Due to a dispute with BT, which owns the cables, Virgin was not able to obtain the access required to launch its digital service in the area.<ref>http://www.ispreview.co.uk/story/2011/04/04/bt-and-virgin-media-dispute-holds-back-faster-broadband-and-tv-in-milton-keynes-uk.html ISPreview – BT and Virgin Media Dispute Holds Back Faster Broadband and TV in Milton Keynes</ref> **February – The [[V+]] box stops being available to new customers as it starts to be phased out in favour of [[TiVo]] boxes. **8 February – For the first time, a UK cable company moves into profit when Virgin Media announces a small profit for 2011.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/feb/08/virgin-media-posts-first-ever-profit Virgin Media posts first ever profit]</ref> **13 September – Movies-on-demand service [[FilmFlex]] is renamed Virgin Movies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mediacentre.virginmedia.com/Stories/New-look-on-demand-movies-unveiled-by-Virgin-Media-23f4.aspx|title=New look on demand movies unveiled by Virgin Media|date=13 September 2012}}</ref> *'''2013''' **6 February – [[Virgin Media]] is bought by [[Liberty Global]] at a cost of £15 billion.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/feb/06/virgin-media-takeover-john-malone-liberty-global Virgin Media bought by Liberty Global for £15 billion]</ref> **2 April – [[Vintage TV (TV channel)|Vintage TV]] launches on channel 343.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cableforum.uk/board/showthread.php?t=33607636&page=57 |title=Virgin Media Changelog page 57|publisher=Cable Forum |date=2 April 2013 |accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref> **15 August – [[BT Sport]] starts broadcasting on Virgin Media, a month after the channel's launch. Virgin makes the channel available in its XL package as had been the case with [[Setanta Sports]] and with ESPN.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/aug/15/bt-sport-virgin-media-tv BT sport channels to be made available to VM TV customers]</ref> **25 October – Four years after launching, [[Premier Sports]] finally becomes available on Virgin Media. It launches one day prior to the start of the [[2013 Rugby League World Cup]] and is available to all viewers until early 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://about.virginmedia.com/press-release/9403/premier-sports-launches-on-virgin-media |title=Premier Sports launches on Virgin Media |publisher=Virgin Media |date=25 October 2013 |accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref> **28 November – Virgin Media shuts down its analogue service in [[Milton Keynes]]. As was the case in Westminster, BT and Virgin Media were not able to reach an agreement allowing Virgin the physical access needed to launch its digital service. *'''2014''' ** 3 February – [[Virgin Media]] acquires [[Smallworld Fibre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://about.virginmedia.com/press-release/9415/virgin-media-acquires-smallworld-fibre |title=Virgin Media acquires Smallworld Fibre |publisher=Virgin Media |date=3 February 2014 |accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> The deal saw Smallworld's network merged into Virgin Media's during 2014. ** 12 May – Virgin Media signs a new five-year deal with Sky but the deal still does not allow for the carriage of [[Sky Atlantic]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/may/12/virgin-media-bskyb-deal-sky-atlantic VM extends BSkyB channels deal]</ref> *'''2015''' ** 5 January – The HD versions of [[Sky News]] and [[Sky Sports News|Sky Sports News HQ]] launch.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cableforum.uk/board/showthread.php?t=33607636&page=68 |title=Virgin Media Changelog page 68|publisher=Cable Forum |date=5 January 2015 |accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref> *'''2016''' ** 12 January – ***Virgin Media launches four music channels but they are only available as an app to [[TiVo]] customers by pressing the red button on channel 345. This is the first time that Virgin Media has launched channels in this way. Later in 2016, one of the channels – [[Clubland TV]] – launches as a linear channel meaning that it can be viewed by non-Tivo customers with the other channels accessible by pressing red.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cableforum.uk/board/showthread.php?t=33607636&page=73 |title=Virgin Media Changelog page 73|publisher=Cable Forum |date=9 October 2016 |accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref> ***Virgin Media also adds the [[Vevo]] streaming music service, again only for [[Tivo]] customers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cableforum.uk/board/showthread.php?t=33607636&page=71 |title=Virgin Media Changelog page 71|publisher=Cable Forum |date=14 January 2016 |accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref> ** 24 August – [[Sky Sports|Sky Sports Mix]] launches and is available from day one on Virgin Media. Also launching on the platform at around the same time are a number of channels already available on Freeview, including [[5Spike|Spike]], [[truTV (UK and Ireland)|truTV]] and [[Sony Movie Channel (UK)|Movie Mix]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cableforum.uk/board/showthread.php?t=33607636&page=73 |title=Virgin Media Changelog page 73|publisher=Cable Forum |date=24 August 2016 |accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref> *'''2017''' ** 10 April – Virgin TV Kids launches, replacing Tiddlers TV.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cableforum.uk/board/showthread.php?t=33607636&page=74 |title=Virgin Media Changelog page 74|publisher=Cable Forum |date=10 April 2017 |accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref> ** 1 June – [[Talking Pictures TV]] launches on channel 445, two years after it launched on other platforms.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cableforum.uk/board/showthread.php?t=33607636&page=74 |title=Virgin Media Changelog page 74|publisher=Cable Forum |date=1 June 2017 |accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref> ** 18 July – [[Sky Sports]] is revamped with the numbered channels being replaced by sports-specific channels. These include two channels dedicated to football, a cricket channel and a golf channel. Other sports are moved to two new channels – Action and Arena – and a showcase channel called Sky Sports Main Event is launched which features simulcasts of the top events being show on Sky Sports that day. Whilst Sky sells them as individual channels, Virgin Media customers have to take all the channels or none at all. *'''2018''' **8 February – Virgin Media signs its first deal with a US streaming service when it announces a partnership with [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] to co-fund a sci-fi series ''[[The Feed (TV series)|The Feed]]''.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/feb/08/virgin-media-deal-sci-fi-series-amazon-the-feed VM signs deal to make sci-fi series with Amazon]</ref> **21 July – A number of channels launch on Virgin Media. They include [[FreeSports]], [[Paramount Network (UK & Ireland)|Paramount Network HD]], [[YourTV]], [[Vice Media|Vice]], [[Horse & Country TV]] and [[Now 80s]], which had previously only been available behind the red button of [[Clubland TV]]. Also, two channel from Canadian company [[Blue Ant Media]] – children's channel [[ZooMoo]] and [[Love Nature]] – launch. Both are exclusive to Virgin Media in the UK.<ref>[https://community.virginmedia.com/t5/News/New-Channel-Line-up/ba-p/3775403 New Channel Line-up]</ref> ** 22 July – The [[UKTV]] channels stop broadcasting on [[Virgin Media]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/jul/22/four-million-virgin-media-customers-lose-uktv-channels-dave Four million Virgin Media customers lose UKTV channels]</ref> The dispute receives considerable media attention.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vqTOnlFmnlk Virgin Media Television and UKTV bosses go head-to-head live on BBC Breakfast]</ref> **27 July – Virgin Media agrees a new three-year deal with [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] after more than a year of discussions.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jul/27/virgin-media-reaches-deal-itv-access-channels Virgin Media reaches deal with ITV to retain access to its channels]</ref> **30 July – [[BT Sport]]’s 4K HD channel launches for Virgin Media customers.<ref>[https://www.a516digital.com/2018/07/bt-and-virgin-media-have-signed-new.html BT and Virgin Media deal: BT UHD channel coming to cable TV]</ref> **11 August – The [[UKTV]] channels return to Virgin Media. The long term deal sees the HD versions of [[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]] and [[Gold (UK TV channel)|Gold]] launch on Virgin Media.<ref>[http://www.virginmedia.com/corporate/media-centre/press-releases/uktv-channels-return-to-virgin-tv.html UKTV channels return to Virgin Media]</ref> **17 September – Virgin Media launches a linear UHD channel. This will be Virgin's first linear television channel since it sold its linear channels to Sky in 2010 and it will broadcast a mix of drama, documentaries and music to customers who have its premium set-top box.<ref>[https://www.a516digital.com/2018/09/virgin-launches-linear-uhd-tv-channel.html Virgin launches linear UHD TV channel]</ref> **25 September – Virgin Media replaces two standard definition channels with their high definition version - the channels in question are [[Gold (UK TV channel)|Gold]] and [[FreeSports]]. Previously when VM had launched high definition channels it had continued to make their SD version available.
